article.title: electron scattering
article.p:
electron scattering
, deflection of the path of
electrons
as they pass through a solid (typically a
metal
,
semiconductor
, or
insulator
). Deflections, or collisions, are caused by electrostatic forces operating between the negatively charged electrons and
atoms
within the solid (
see
quantum electrodynamics
). These forces reduce the speed of the electrons, thereby limiting the performance of electronic devices based on
transistors
and
integrated circuits
. The deflection of a beam of electrons by a target also is called electron scattering and has been used to probe the size and charge distribution of atomic nuclei. In the early 1970s, electron scattering helped to confirm that
protons
and
neutrons
are made of still more elementary
subatomic particles
known as
quarks
.
See also
cross section
and
electron diffraction
.
